page.title: 04HOUSING
page.content: HOUSING IN BRASSINGTON AND DISTRICT 1600's - notable houses of the period which survive today include Tudor House. Ivy Bank and Sundial Cottage. The George (opp.the church) is of slate and plaster, rest of stone construction. 1700's - Two or three storied stone houses built in Well St, King's Hill & Town St - to house farmers and lead mine owners & interspaced with cottages for their respective workers. Farm houses in the outlying area were often small and added to as required. Many public houses needed when Brassington was a staging post on the turnpike route London - Manchester, are now private houses e.g. the Dragon. 1800's - Barns adapted to houses, Park Close 1832, purpose built homes, Manse (Cliffe Cottage)1830's, bricks used
